title: How would I improve Archlight Vayne skin texture
body:
I edited the new Vayne skin, so that it would look more like the splash art. I'm not saying it's better, or more correct, it's just closer to how I would prefer it.

http://i1196.photobucket.com/albums/aa404/listek000/League/archlight_zpsgin1wg3m.png

- I thought the texture was too toned down, so I added more contrast
- darker skin color is not necessarily closer to the splash, but I thought it would fit better
- I made the body marks more visible and eyes more shiny
- I added more folds on the cloth and some other changed details, including shadows from armor
- I made the gold parts more like metal with added details, mostly based on the splash
- I changed hair and hairline, so it looks more organic

replies.body: Good thing I ain't buying a flawed design of the skin.
the skin is right from art perspective, you can't apply light/shadow on the model in game since there's no clear direction for the light like in the splash art

> [{quoted}](name=DemiluniS,realm=NA,application-id=A8FQeEA8,discussion-id=Qoz1ehgc,comment-id=00020000,timestamp=2015-04-21T23:33:25.201+0000)
>
> the skin is right from art perspective, you can't apply light/shadow on the model in game since there's no clear direction for the light like in the splash art

Despite the lighting, the texturing is off in the released model next to its splash art depiction. The one he modified is closer to what the clothing textures should look like.

Also! Splashes and in-game models are never exactly the same. Splashes allow for artistic expression in order to convey the story or theme of the skin, while the in-game model is first and foremost optimized for game clarity.

Two different things!

Then can we please have some way to view skins in client? Because there are several skins than are completely different between splash and in-game. It kinda feels like false advertising if they are allowed to look incredibly different and we are only allowed to see the one that doesn't matter.
www.lolking.net/models

Which is explicitly why I mentioned 'in client'. Yes, I know you can go to lolking and see the skin spotlight videos.

You shouldn't have to.

I know I know, but that would actually take _a lot_ of programming, not even starting to mention the possible  issues that could occur.

If you haven't noticed, the out of game client and the in game client are separate applications that draw data from separate locations and use different resources. Meaning that the out of game client would have to get a huge remodel in programming in order to be able to render and display the models.

Not only that, but you're talking about adding an entirely new section to the client- where does it fit in? You would have to redesign many aspects in order to just have the model viewer there.

What about the level of detail on the models? Changing the level of quality so that you could check what the model looks like at a lower level would matter a lot to players who have to run on the lowest specs just to play the game.

While it's a brilliant and logical idea, in practice is just. Doesn't. Work.

I'm sorry, I don't take 'it'd be hard' as an excuse. I realize that the current client is terrible, but that's a reason to make a new client, not just give up on good ideas because they can't currently do things.

It's not that it's just hard, it's that the expense outweighs the reward.
**_I would love it to work, trust me._**
However in this case the excuse is the reason they won't do it, Riot wouldn't spend resources into a project that doesn't return in capital. Cash. Money. $$$.
Welcome to Capitalism {{item:3070}}

The entire point of capitalism is 'make people want to buy things'. I'm sure there are several people who would buy more skins if they could see what they look like in the client, instead of having to go to a different website. It might bring in more snap judgement purchases.
The amount of money to make this work outweighs the benefit/profit. Riot probably makes more money off people impulse buying based off the splash arts than they would from implementing the system.

Incentive being other games like heroes of the storm are beating riot to it and implementing things in alpha/beta that league should have had at least a couple years in but now we're nearing year 6 if not more with league and still not seeing much improvement with hud, client, and features of the client such as profile, store etc. League is really falling behind. There is no excuse there could not be videos or screen shots of them as such when they demonstrate abilities. 

If they cannot even do that part when many other games are currently demonstrating 3d views of their cosmetics then perhaps league just couldn't give a crap and only makes splashes to sell skins rather than tell a story or get into the darkness of a theme of a skin. Very unethical and lazy. But given my perception on the company has dramatically taken a turn over the years. So, at the end of the day I just remind myself never to have high expectations. Have far below average expectations and you can't really be disappointed or amazed!
surrenderat20 has prewievs in game that provide good picture about how the skin will look like in the game.

I'm aware. That's besides the point; it's for people who don't know about those websites, or people that don't want to go to many league related websites. You're purchasing the skin in the client, so why can't you see what you're buying in the client?

I get it.

And I agree, it sure would be nice to see it in the client.

Though you dont need to know any league related sites. Jut put the name of your skin in google. And unless it is brand new, you will surely find one. Just sayin.

> [{quoted}](name=Riot Baconhawk,realm=NA,application-id=A8FQeEA8,discussion-id=Qoz1ehgc,comment-id=0002000000000000,timestamp=2015-04-22T03:04:42.429+0000)
>
> Also! Splashes and in-game models are never exactly the same. Splashes allow for artistic expression in order to convey the story or theme of the skin, while the in-game model is first and foremost optimized for game clarity.
> 
> Two different things!

Still, the torso texture doesnt look anything like the one in the splash art.  A slight modification of that texture wouldnt have been a lot of work and it will still follow the clarity thing.

but lets face facts here... the breastplate and cami underneath it are vastly different in game compared to the splash. It is a completely different design in front on the splash. The Breastplate's point leading to the lower torso comes down further, the blue tapers toward the center diamond shape on the belt of the skirt. the rest is white on the sides... not blue. How the heck did the in game design become so varied in comparison to the splash? It is a pretty huge misrepresentation whichever way you compare them. If I were to pick up this skin only to notice some of the cooler details were completely left out... lets just say I wouldn't be very satisfied with my purchase and would probably refund it to get something else.

It's still a fact that her skin is too pale. The in game clarity would be increased if her little golden lines actually contrasted off of a darker skin tone. Right now, her revealed skin, especially on her face, is just way too light, concealing her expression and the golden lines in whiteness, almost like a glare. The person who colored the in-game model had both a poor artistic eye and a poor eye for in game clarity. This is coming from a multi-thousand game Vayne main and professional artist who appreciates the skin but is still disappointed in the final product. It's simply a disappointment to a discerning eye.

I think they should have kept this skin on the PBE for just a bit longer until they fixed the texturing, like they did with Debonair Galio.

The one comment I have is make sure you put this paintover side-by-side on Summoner's Rift, which is what these skins are designed against, and at gameplay angle.

You've done a great job making this specific pose look lovely, but there's definintely a reason she's lighter on top and darker toward the bottom, with less strong contrasty elements. (I am no official Riot artist but I'm on the skins team). This is stuff we talk about all the time!
To be honest, even in-game it's easily noticeable that the lack of contrast on her model is a little too much, especially on her clothes and armor.

No one is arguing that a lot of thought went into the making of the model, but you have to understand many of us are unhappy with it. I like what the OP did and I think that his idea strikes right into the {{champion:67}}  (drumroll) of what we are all feeling about the model.

Well, that is true. I didn't really work on it in connection with the background (Summoner's Rift), so maybe it would look terrible. I'd check, but my PBE is still updating.

However, a lot of recent skins (and old skin re-textured) are very simplified in detail, which I'm sure it's on purpose, I just don't agree with it. For example hair strands are barely visible and there are very little details on clothing and armor. Yes, those details wouldn't be very noticeable in game from a top view, however, when people know something, it usually bothers them even if they can't see it most of the time. 
Hair strands on the other hand, look less good when close up, but better when from far top view. Which is why I am a bit confused by the decision to make hair less contrasted, as it makes it look more like a helm then hair. If you check any recent skin re-work news posts (for ex. Poppy one) you will know what I mean (as well as this Vayne skin).
What about Twisted Treeling, Crystal Scar and Howling Abyss? Don't leave them out! {{item:3070}}

There's nothing wrong with the edited version fitting into rift. While I appreciate the effort from the skin team it clearly fell short and the splash art does not just give the artists a way to express the story or theme of the skin it is made to sell. In most cases a majority of the splash arts can be extremely misleading, which is why in heroes of the storm 3d models are shown of the skin you are about to purchase. Why league has never implemented something of the sort baffles me.

 ALTHOUGH if people really wanted to see the skin they could go online and look but that is just expecting the consumer to go the extra mile. There's no reason the skin couldn't have better matched the splash art. The textures probably took the OP less than 10 minutes to enhance and you'd expect better time management and editing from riot. I mean no disrespect but it is really insulting to the community when people from the riot team insist on X reason why Y was no implemented. Whether it be features, game mechanics, skins, models, animations or balances. The more popular reasons being priorities and or clarity. 

I don't see how minor changes to the skin would impact priorities or even clarity. We'll see though... A shame splash arts are just meant to hype you for the skin and purchase it and then only to be disappointed. And then only limit people refunds. I didn't buy the vayne skin and to my knowledge I've never used a refund. But I believe this principal can be applied to most skins released in the following years. I think league has done better by showing the models in posts but there should be more "clarity" hue in the store. But also I think there should be more effort to make these skins much more badass.
The models can still be predominantly lighter on top and darker on the bottom while maintaining enough contrast for the faces to look alive...or at least to have the little golden lines pop more.
